metadata.synopsis: First dialogue with Hope's spirit that happens after players get to House of Hope.Hope is a captive within the House, and has been driven mad by years of psychological and physical torture. Raphael keeps her alive because she astonishes him - and the reason for that is that no matter what he does to her, she holds onto the last of her hope and optimism. That fascinates him.In this dialogue, Hope introduces players to the House of Hope. They have arrived here deliberately, knowing that they are not invited, and that it is likely dangerous.Hope appears to warn them of that danger, and to help them, and also introduces the deranged vibe of the area.Note: When Hope speaks in all-caps, she is showing the manic side of her personality. Louder, more intense, and almost like she's possessed by a different, more deranged version of herself.

117.context: CinematicNodeContext: flickers into view, and curtseysNodeContext: a sad welcome. Rhyme is intentional and playful. Speaking softly

28.text: CURIOSITY KILLED ALL THE CATS IT WON'T BE SO KIND TO YOU
28.context: NodeContext: voice raised, but not at full volume. A warning.

157.speaker: Narrator
157.text: *As the woman speaks, you hear a distant rattle of chains, and she winces in pain.*

60.text: Ah the jailor will hear us. I shouldn't be talking to you. I must go. It's not kind to me.
60.context: NodeContext: subdued, just experienced a short sharp pain and is trying to be on her best behaviour. Heavy emphasis on 'it's' - she's not saying what it is, but wants us to realise it is an it rather than a them.

13.speaker: Narrator
13.text: *The figure flickers and starts to dim from view. But you sense she could be convinced to return.*

166.speaker: Player
166.text: Wait - don't go. Who are you?

109.speaker: Narrator
109.text: *The figure shimmers brightly. Your words seem to have piqued her curiosity.*

50.text: Who am I? It's my favourite question. I scream it into the dark while I sleep, and whisper it to my memories when I wake.
50.context: NodeContext: excited to talk about the central horror of her life - she is 'hope', and she's desperately clinging on to her sense of self, and the meaning of the word 'hope;.

150.text: I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart.
150.context: NodeContext: excited to talk about the central horror of her life - she is 'hope', and she's desperately clinging on to her sense of self, and the meaning of the word 'hope;.

8.text: I am Hope. What little is left of her.
8.context: NodeContext: proud, and sad. 'Hope' is her actual name, as well as the thing she represents

113.text: A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT

145.speaker: Karlach
145.text: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
145.context: NodeContext: A little bitter, a little sympathetic.

161.text: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse?
161.context: NodeContext: sad, but increasingly excited at the possibility of finding a friend

39.text: Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
39.context: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking

40.speaker: Lae'zel
40.text: You must ask of the Orphic Hammer. Without it, the prince remains forever out of reach of my hungry weapon.
40.context: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking

68.context: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking

56.speaker: Player
56.text: I need to find my contract. Can you help?

126.text: Caveat venditor. Big mistake coming here while Raphael holds all the cards in his claws.
126.context: NodeContext: first phrase, Latin for 'let the seller beware'. Player just told her that they made a contract with a devil and she's agreeing that was a STUPID thing to do.

102.text: But big mistakes correct bigger mistakes. Like scribbling your signature in the first place. Silly little mouse.

16.text: But, yes. Hope can help. Your contract is here, in this House - it's...
16.context: NodeContext: Enthusiasm starts to come through. Referring to herself in third-person very naturally. Interrupted by sudden shock of pain on last word, but we don't hear it in this node - she's just cut off

79.speaker: Narrator
79.text: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*

34.context: NodeContext: long pause between shhhtt and quiet - she's convincing the player and herself to stay quiet while her jailor leaves her cell

98.text: Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid.
98.context: NodeContext: hurriedly, and with a confident note on the final phrase

70.text: I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
70.context: CinematicNodeContext: Player receives glamour, Hope raises her hands in front of her chest and wiggles her fingers enthusiasitcally to cast the spellNodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player

134.text: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
134.context: NodeContext: speaking in hushed tones. Heavy emphasis on concentrate.'little wretch' is affectoinate

81.speaker: Player
81.text: Focus on speaking as quietly and calmly as possible.

4.context: NodeContext: speaking almost in a whisper

76.speaker: Player
76.text: I need to find the Orphic Hammer. Where is it?

132.text: Discovered an ancient gith prince in need of a saviour? The Orphic Hammer is the perfect tool for breaking all infernal chains.
132.context: NodeContext: Manic, like a salesman's patter, heavy emphasis on all, drawing the word out

120.speaker: Player
120.text: Why has Raphael been following me?

87.text: HE LOVES YOU HE LOVES YOU NOT HE LOVES YOU HE LOVES YOU NOT
87.context: NodeContext: manic repetitive, growing louder on every phrase, but not reaching full volume

158.speaker: Player
158.text: What Hammer are you talking about?

164.text: THE ONE THAT RAT-A-TATTED THE CHAINS IN PLACE AND BROKE THE FUTURE
164.context: NodeContext: sing-song on 'rat-a-tatted' - she enjoys the sound of the rhyme.

26.speaker: Player
26.text: Where will I find my contract?

167.text: THE SAME PLACE YOU'LL FIND YOUR SORRY LITTLE SOUL WHEN RAPHAEL RIPS IT OUT
167.context: NodeContext: a hint of sudden malice as she raises her voice - not angry, but seeming to enjoy the horrors she's talking about a little

32.text: The paper cage for your soul. Such a tiny thing, but it's one of his favourites.
32.context: NodeContext: composing herself rapidly on first phrase, after an outburst on previous line. speaking softly about the 'contract' in flowery terms as if speaking of something precious and fragile

65.text: In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you.
65.context: NodeContext: hurried instructions until 'OH!', which is a self-interruption. She just reminded herself of the debtos and now she needs to warn you about them

14.text: But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.
14.context: NodeContext: excited, like a kid making a friend for the first time, and then immediately doubting it. Her internal thoughts spilling out of her

61.text: Can you save me? PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE.
61.context: NodeContext: with a great deal of excited anticipation on the question, and is too excied to wait for an answer and starts to beg

85.context: NodeContext: with a sad, desperate laugh

107.speaker: Player
107.text: If I can, I will. What needs to be done?

41.text: All right. You have to listen very very very closely. I will say this only once.
41.context: NodeContext: quiet, serious, getting to the point

140.speaker: Karlach
140.text: Find the KEY. Take the Hammer. Smash my chains. Find the key. Take the HAMMER. Smash my chains. Find the key. Take the Hammer. Smash my CHAINS.
140.context: NodeContext: sing-song, the noun that she's emphasising on each repetition is the MOST important part

130.text: But be careful. Once you take the Hammer, the fire will come. And Raphael. You must run run run run.
130.context: NodeContext:  despite the dire situation, she's enjoying the dramatic build-up

118.text: Find the KEY. Take the contract. Smash my chains. Find the key. Take the CONTRACT. Smash my chains. Find the key. Take the contract. Smash my CHAINS.
118.context: NodeContext: sing-song, the noun that she's emphasising on each repetition is the MOST important part

129.text: And bring the Hammer. I hope you didn't drop it, I hope you didn't lose it.
129.context: NodeContext: this is very important, she's fretting on the second sentence, expecting the worst

77.text: Once you take the contract, the fire will come. And Raphael. You must run run run.
77.context: NodeContext:  despite the dire situation, she's enjoying the dramatic build-up

148.text: But don't forget me. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE. I don't want to burn. Not again.
148.context: NodeContext: desperate outburst on the PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE, begging. Then recomposes herself for the final two sentences, which are serious and sad.

160.speaker: Karlach
160.text: We won't! We'll get you out. I promise.
160.context: NodeContext: Talking to Hope, but subtext talking to herself

45.speaker: Narrator
45.text: *The rattle of chains echoes louder, from unseen places. And without a scream or a sigh, Hope disappears.*

127.speaker: Player
127.text: No, I don't have time for this.

95.text: I BROUGHT YOU HOPE YOU BROUGHT DESPAIR YOU WILL BURN BURN BURN
95.context: NodeContext: manic, disappointed and sad. pause between the 'BURN's as she increases the volume

149.speaker: Player
149.text: First answer more of my questions.

103.text: NO NO NO NO NO. It's my turn.
103.context: NodeContext: tantrum, increasing volume on 'nos' Childish.

31.text: I never asked this of anybody. Nobody was capable, nobody was worthy, nobody was good enough. But you, you have it all.

89.speaker: Player
89.text: No. I'm not telling you anything.

67.speaker: Player
67.text: What dangers should I prepare for?

146.text: CAN THE FLY PREPARE FOR THE SPIDER? CAN THE SOUP PREPARE FOR THE SPOON? YOU'RE DEAD DEAD DEAD
146.context: NodeContext: manic - increasing volume. Dire warnings

78.text: All of them. The traps and the monsters and the humongous balls of fire.
78.context: NodeContext: composing herself rapidly on first phrase, after an outburst on previous line. Hurriedly rushing through the threats on the second sentence

24.speaker: Player
24.text: Is there any way I can help you?

80.text: YOU CAN'T HELP ME YOU CAN'T EVEN HELP YOURSELF YOU'RE GOING TO DIE HERE
80.context: NodeContext: volume raised, intense fear with a manic edge

54.text: You ask after me rather than your own heart's desire? It would bring a tear to my eye if I had not shed them all so long ago.
54.context: NodeContext: composing herself rapidly on first phrase, after an outburst on previous line, Not self-pitying on the rest, just honest

104.text: The Hammer is the key, for you and for me.
104.context: NodeContext: sing-song, enjoying the rhyme, heavy emphasis on 'and'

51.text: The Hammer Raphael gave you is the key, for you and for me.
51.context: NodeContext: sing-song, enjoying the rhyme, heavy emphasis on 'and'

53.text: BUT YOU MUST HAVE LEFT IT IN YOUR OTHER TROUSERS BECAUSE IT ISN'T HERE
53.context: NodeContext: alarmed that the player doesn't have what she needs

72.context: NodeContext: like the audience at a pantomime - nobody is actually behind us, she's just playing a trick

3.text: Skipping across the planes, spinning plates, making deals with dukes and devils. He's a busy man. A business-man. But not a man at all, of course.
3.context: NodeContext: composing herself rapidly on first phrase, after an outburst on previous line. Trying to unpick her own thoughts here as she tries to give important information but gets caught up on the formulation of 'business-man', a term she's inadvertently coining

29.text: He'll be home soon, though, and you better find your contract before he arrives.

66.text: I read it. There are precisely forty-nine clauses and subsections that give him the authority to tear out your soul if he finds you here uninvited.
66.context: NodeContext: proud on first phrase, as if expecting a reward (I DID A THING) - but quickly moves on to dire warning for the rest

48.text: You really should have had someone clever look that thing over before you signed.
48.context: NodeContext: disappointed in the player - we REALLY should have known better

38.text: He'll be home soon, though, and you better find the Hammer before he arrives.

52.text: IT HEARS YOUR THOUGHTS IT HEARS HOPE'S HEART BEATING
52.context: NodeContext: dismay, not shouting, but voice raised in panic

44.speaker: Player
44.text: Prepare to speak in your finest stage whisper.

84.speaker: Player
84.text: Formulate your questions using as few words as possible.

119.speaker: Player
119.text: Speak soft as the breeze-caught melody.

63.speaker: Player
63.text: Make your words soft as the assassin's footfall.

62.speaker: Player
62.text: Try really hard not to roar your words.

101.speaker: Player
101.text: Whisper as you would in the depths of a hunt.

142.speaker: Player
142.text: Assume the familiar quietude of a student in a grand library.

75.speaker: Player
75.text: Whisper as you would in most intimate prayer.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: Emulate the quiet of a peaceful glade.

94.speaker: Player
94.text: Recall the hush before the roar of battle.

151.speaker: Player
151.text: Be like the eye of a storm - quiet among the chaos.

124.speaker: Player
124.text: Speak as the words of revenge whispered in a dying sinner's ear.

6.speaker: Player
6.text: Why has Raphael been following me?

138.text: You're the key to his future kingdom. You're his crowning glory. He has what you need but you are what he needs.

122.text: Not a cure, no, not that. But a Hammer to break your chains. Or his chains.

47.speaker: Player
47.text: I need to find the Orphic Hammer. Can you help?

74.text: Hope can help. The Hammer is here, in this House - it's...

88.speaker: Player
88.text: Lead me to the Orphic Hammer. I will not leave without it.

55.text: Raphael's House of Hope. But your question was hopeless. You already knew that.

133.text: Don't waste any more words, or we'll both be sorry.

92.text: The House is home to many things. Most will kill you, one can save you. The Hammer - the Hammer that breaks the chains. You must steal it!

37.text: The House is home to many things. Most of them really want to kill you.

30.text: I strongly suggest you try not to let that happen. Find your contract instead - save your soul!

25.text: You brilliant, beautiful maniac! I'll hold him down while you trim his arteries.

115.text: EXCEPT HE'S NOT HOME I'M INDISPOSED AND YOU'RE IN HELL

20.text: The many eyes. The stare of pain. The ray of death. Keep it away. Keep it away.

144.speaker: Player
144.text: I'm done with this. You're mad.

137.text: Don't you find my nonsense pretty? Then an ugly warning, loud and clear, like a sailor's shout as the rocks pierce through the fog.
137.context: NodeContext: surprised on first phrase, and then resigned to jumping into the 'ugly warning' she was trying to avoid

2.text: TURN BACK AHOY AVAST ALACK OUR HULL WILL HAVE A BROKEN BACK
2.context: NodeContext: Wailing in mock-distress - the rhyme is deliberate.

147.text: But I really do want to help you.

155.speaker: Lae'zel
155.text: You must ask of the Orphic Hammer. Without it, the Prince of the Comet - and the githyanki people - remain forever chained.
155.context: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking

165.speaker: Lae'zel
165.text: This place must house our contract with Raphael. If Hope points the way, we might take it - and shred it.
165.context: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking

7.text: I can't leave, I can only suffer. But I'm supposed to do that in silence. Everyone here hates me for what I am.

139.speaker: Player
139.text: Maybe I can help you be free of whoever's hurting you.

114.text: I hope so. But it is a faint hope. Just like me.
114.context: NodeContext: with a sad but hopeful smile

153.speaker: Player
153.text: Good riddance. The last thing I need now is a mad apparition.

96.speaker: Narrator
96.text: *The atmosphere of the room is oppressive, the heat claustrophobic. Beneath your feet, the stone ripples, as if breathing softly.*

110.speaker: Narrator
110.text: *The diabolist's ritual was no parlour trick. If you had any doubts, they evaporate the moment you arrive. You are in the Hells.*

163.text: It is so good to see you again! I can't tell you how glad I am that you didn't enter the House without me.

82.speaker: Player
82.text: I didn't have a choice - the door's locked.

21.text: I'm sure a locked door can't stop a brave adventurer like you. But even if you poke the locks or knock-knock-knock, you won't get far without me.

111.speaker: Player
111.text: I thought you were going to leave.
